subject: order of letters for learning
msgSnippet: Hi Group, I am currently learning to write and read Quikscript. I followed Read s manual and started with the letters .tea and .no, as well as .it, .eat, .et,
messageBody:
Hi Group,
I am currently learning to write and read Quikscript. I followed
Read's manual and started with the letters .tea and .no, as well as
.it, .eat, .et, .eight, and .at. These are really great, because they
form so many words. I even found ones that weren't in the manual, such
as "teen", "tenant", and "eighty". Then I added the letter .aye to the
pack and found a lot of words that I could write. But then I got
stuck: for .ah and .awe, I did not find any words which use only
letters previously learned, while for .ox I found only "on", and for
.oy I found only "toy" and "annoy" (at least).
Now, I am thinking that to make learning easier, I should maybe add
some of the more frequent consonants before I learn the less frequent
vowels. Of I course I could study it brute-force and just write
whatever comes to my head, looking up every letter as I need it, but I
want to make it a more pleasant and more efficient experience. Also,
once I have figured out a nice order, I would publish it along with a
list of example words, so that other people could use it, too.
Now here's my question: do you have any suggestion for the order of
letters for learning? and maybe even some example words (or phrases)?
thanks!
Jack
